description: From Middle English howlen, houlen, from Old English *hūlian, from Proto-West Germanic *hūwilōn, from Proto-Germanic *hūwilōną, *hiuwilōną (“to howl”), from Proto-Indo-European *kū-, *kew- (“to howl, scream”).

Cognate with Saterland Frisian huulje (“to howl”), Dutch huilen (“to howl”), Old French ouler, German Low German hulen (“to howl”), German heulen (“to howl”), Danish hyle (“to howl”), Swedish yla (“to scream, yell”), Northern Luri آلٛیر‎ (āłir, “howl”).

entries.meaning: The protracted, mournful cry of a dog, wolf or other canid; also of other animals.
A prolonged cry of distress or anguish; a wail.

verbs.description: howl (third-person singular simple present howls, present participle howling, simple past and past participle howled)

entries.meaning: To utter a loud, protracted, mournful sound or cry, as dogs and wolves often do.
To utter a sound expressive of pain or distress; to cry aloud and mournfully; to lament; to wail.
To make a noise resembling the cry of a wild beast.
examples: They howled with laughter at the prank.
